content.content: MIP4c2-SP28: Amend MIP51 to remove MIP51c4: Calendar Exceptions  Preamble MIP4c2-SP#: 28 MIP to be amended: MIP51 Author(s): @ultraschuppi Contributors: Tags: governance-cycle, mip-amendment, process Status: Rejected Date Proposed: 2022-11-03 Date Ratified: N/A Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip4c2-sp28-amend-mip51-to-remove-the-calendar-exception/18675 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/QmSNy5NT   Specification  Motivation The December exception in MIP51 has been made in a time with huge problems on getting anything done in the Maker on-chain governance. As we have a working delegate system now, this situation has improved a lot — both participation in on-chain polls as well as passing executives is not an issue anymore. This amendment removes the December exception so we can continue to govern the protocol without a break. As the December exception has been the only one so far, this amendment will also remove the containing component as well. If we ever need to make an amendment reintroducing an exception, the component can be reintroduced again.  Amended MIPs and Components Remove MIP51c4: Calendar Exceptions.  Amendment Pull Request   github.com/makerdao/mips         Remove (December) exception for MIP51   makerdao:master ← ultraschuppi:master              opened 05:33PM - 03 Nov 22 UTC                 ultraschuppi               +2 -14       https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip4c3-spx-amend-mip51-to-remove-the-calendar-excep…tion/18675        Relevant Information –

content.content: We also did this because we wanted developers to have a break over the end of December.

I think that the solution is probably having 12 4-week cycles (we can even make the shorter nowadays) that don’t map 1:1 to months. That way you can account for all major holidays? This MIP has been in my backlog (very far down) for like 2 years, so I’m really looking forward to it.

content.content: @ultraschuppi I will trust your experience as we have yet to live through a December cycle. I emphasize points raised by @Derek - we are all human, including delegates. While the original pause may no longer be necessary, it is still valuable giving breaks and allow folks to breathe. Predictable ones - such as the ones outlined in this MIP - around holidays allow folks the opportunity to spend time with their family, travel or individual passions outside crypto. Think about it like a company - the best benefits will attract the best talent. DAOs are asynchronous and will attract folks across multiple time zones, religions, and demographics. Maker now has reached critical mass, buts let’s not ignore the basis of this proposal.

content.content: fig:  I emphasize points raised by @Derek - we are all human, including delegates. While the original pause may no longer be necessary, it is still valuable giving breaks and allow folks to breathe.   Thanks for your comments @fig - a couple from me to counter them: Maker is part of an unstoppable machine. I does not know about closing hours, bank holidays or “months were a lot of people try to enjoy their time-off”. We create redundancy by having multiple people in a team, so people can take time off - and we can probably all agree that it is fine that CoreUnits decide to e.g. not create any spells during a certain timeframe unless hell brakes loose. Same is true for delegates, as more and more teams on the Recognized Delegates appear, that can organize themselves on covering those timeframes despite most of their members taking vacations. We already have pretty long-cycled times on most adjustments that go through the MIP cycle, most of the stuff should actually be addressed and sorted out during the RFC period. The issues that are to be decided are quite the opposite of rushed or having a short noticed period. The main reason why we started with the December-exception was because we had issues with getting MKR holders to vote on polls or pass executives. This is no longer the case - we have a pretty good turnout on polls and our ability to pass executives is good enough. Speaking as a Recognized Delegate: I feel that the bar we have for participation in the governance system is already pretty low - and I am even running solo. Imagine Budget proposals that get downvoted shortly before December and that cannot go into a rerun before January. The calendar exception creates an artificial bureaucratic constraint that we can get rid off.
